items.title: how to extract return?
items.body:
Hello,

At the moment I extract the iso_code as follows:
`/usr/bin/mmdblookup -f /var/lib/GeoIP/GeoLite2-Country.mmdb -i IP country iso_code | sed 's/[^"]*"\([^"]*\)".*/\1/' | xargs`

Is there a clean/effective other way to only get the iso_code (ex. US) as return?

PS. Use the code in a bash script.

Thanks in advance.

items.title: Bad GeoIP2-City.mmdb lookup: MMDB_entry_data_s contains illogical data_size and type
items.body:
**Environment is CenOS 6.0
libmaxmind 1.4.2**

Flow: 
MMDB_SUCCESS == MMDB_open ()
MMDB_lookup_string(): 0 != gai_error and MMDB_SUCCESS != mmdb_error

And than:

	MMDB_entry_data_s countryData = { 0 };
	int status = MMDB_get_value(&(result.entry), &countryData, "country", "iso_code", NULL);
	if ((status == 0)
		&& (countryData.has_data) 
		&& (countryData.type == MMDB_DATA_TYPE_UTF8_STRING))
	{
		Country = PooledString(countryData.utf8_string, countryData.utf8_string + countryData.data_size);
	} 
	else
	{
		LOGGER_WARN("Cant fetch Country. status: " << status << ",  countryData.has_data: " 
			<< countryData.has_data << ", countryData.data_size: " << countryData.data_size 
			<< ", countryData.type: " << countryData.type);
	}

Produces this log:

WARN 12 Mar 2020 09:26:35.802 IPV6: [21122:139928515954624]: GeoIP2Helper.cpp:102[getRegionByAddress]: Cant fetch Country. status: 0,  countryData.has_data: true, countryData.data_size: 178, countryData.type: 181

**Problem: Expecting data_size and type to be 2 (two chars, utf8 type).**

**More information:**
1. Failed on Linux, works OK on Windows 32 compilation
2. Tested with 3 different file – same results.
3. Dumping the results, as MMDB_entry_data_list_s as a big json-like buffer succeeded on all platforms. I see the entries are there.
4. May be memory/types/compilation issue.

Thanks,
Adi Ariel
Viber Media Backend Team

items.title: Add flag to make CLI output parsable as standard json / raw-values
items.body:
This ticket is for two very specific feature requests:

**1. When making top-level queries, there should be a way to get the output as standard JSON w/ commas, without type annotations or extra newlines.**
    There's no need to change the default behavior (although that would be ideal), to maintain backwards-compatibility, this can be added as a `--json` flag. This is needed to be parsable as actual JSON by tools like `jq`, and to be usable for any purpose in general without requiring lots of command-line `sed`/`awk` voodoo.  

```bash
$ mmdblookup --file /usr/local/var/GeoIP/GeoLite2-City.mmdb --json --ip 75.37.71.246
{ 
    "city": {
        "geoname_id": 5378538,
        "names": {
            "en": "Oakland",
            ...
        }
    },
    ...
}

# no preceding/trailing empty newlines, no type annotations, + commas added
# makes it usable directly with jq or as JSON, e.g. LOCATION="$(mmdblookup ... --json | jq '.city.names.en,.country.names.en')"
```

**2. When making queries for a specific value, there should be a way to get the value without extra newlines, quotes, or type annotations** (like `jq --raw-value` and many other tools).
    Once again, this is to make it usable in on the CLI / in scripts without requiring lots of `sed`/`awk` painfulness to strip the quotes, type annotation, and newline.

```bash
# if output is a single value, it can just write the plain value to stdout
$ mmdblookup --file /usr/local/var/GeoIP/GeoLite2-City.mmdb --raw-value --ip 75.37.71.246 city names en
Oakland

# no preceding/trailing empty newlines, no type annotations, no quotes (aka standard text, directly pipe-able without extra parsing)
# makes it usable in shell substitutions and many other places, e.g. CITY="$(mddblookup ... --raw-value)"
# (second layer of quotes + everything else makes this significantly harder as-is)

# if output is multiple values, whitespace-separated columns are very easy to parse with awk or other utilities, keys should be on each line to make it grep-able
# alternatively --raw-value could be limited to single-values and `exit 2` if there are multiple values (people can use --json + jq for handling multi-value queries)
$ mmdblookup --file /usr/local/var/GeoIP/GeoLite2-City.mmdb --raw-value --ip 75.37.71.246 city names
en:        Oakland
zh-CN:     奥克兰
...
```

**Reasoning for this feature request:**

This is otherwise a very nice tool, I appreciate the hard work so far and I'd love to be able to use it in a lot of places! But as evidenced by https://github.com/maxmind/libmaxminddb/issues/135, many people have spent a lot of hours trying to wrangle the output of `libmaxminddb` into a usable form. As it stands, the type-annotations-required mode provides negative utility for most use cases, and it seems like a pity to make CLI output un-parsable by pretty much all standard tooling without any flag to change that behavior.

> This is the Unix philosophy: Write programs that do one thing and do it well. Write programs to **work together**. Write programs to handle **text streams**, because that is a universal interface.

items.title: Allow retrieving the matching network
items.body:
Companion bug for https://github.com/maxmind/mod_maxminddb/issues/81

The following ruby script 
```ruby
require 'maxminddb'
db = MaxMindDB.new('GeoLite2-ASN.mmdb')
p db.lookup('1.1.1.1')
```

gives me this output (reformatted for readability):

```
#<MaxMindDB::Result:0x000055a27cd962b8
  @raw={
    "autonomous_system_number"=>13335,
    "autonomous_system_organization"=>"Cloudflare, Inc.",
    "network"=>"1.1.1.0/24"
  }>
```

It would be awesome for the library to allow fetching this information as well. mod_maxminddb and the python-bindings could use it.

items.title: Memory leak of start_threaded_benchmark() in bin\mmdblookup.c
items.body:
![memory leak](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/24968470/57744613-7f3c3880-76fc-11e9-98e8-9480ae1754ea.png)
Function start_threaded_benchmark() is defined in bin\mmdblookup.c.
Function start_threaded_benchmark() calls calloc() on line 629, and assigns a pointer which points to the start address to the variable tinfo. If the program executes to line 638 the function does not return, indicating that tinfo is not NULL and the space allocation is successful. Later, when start_time is equal to -1, the program returns without releasing tinfo on line 640, and a memory leak error has occurred. See the following code:

items.title: libta/tap.h: No such file or directory
items.body:
When I hit that error, I [downloaded tap](https://github.com/zorgnax/libtap) and installed it.  However, it installed tap.h in `/usr/local/include`.  I notice it also installed a `tap.pc`, so maybe you could add `PKG_PROG_PKG_CONFIG` in `configure.ac`, and then set `CFLAGS` using `$PKG_CONFIG --cflags-only-I` or something similar.

As a workaround, I just changed `#include "libtap/tap.h"` with `#include <tap.h>`, and created a `libtap` directory with a dummy Makefile.  That way, make and make check succeeded.

items.title: Libmaxminddb doesn't support file paths outside the current code page on Windows.
items.body:
If I create an account for [Bruce Lee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bruce_Lee) on a Windows 10 system here such that I have a directory named `C:\Users\李小龍` and place GeoLite2-City.mmdb in `C:\Users\李小龍\GeoIP`, mmdblookup returns the following error:

```
> .\mmdblookup --file C:\Users\李小龍\GeoIP\GeoLite2-City.mmdb --ip 8.8.8.8

  Can't open C:\Users\???\GeoIP\GeoLite2-City.mmdb - Error opening the specified MaxMind DB file
```

This appears to be due to libmaxminddb using the narrow (ANSI) version of the Win32 API, specifically CreateFileA:

https://github.com/maxmind/libmaxminddb/blob/master/src/maxminddb.c#L331

Using the ANSI API goes against Microsoft's recommendations. As https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/desktop/intl/conventions-for-function-prototypes says,

"New Windows applications should use Unicode to avoid the inconsistencies of varied code pages and for ease of localization. They should be written with generic functions, and should define UNICODE to compile the functions into Unicode functions. In the few places where an application must work with 8-bit character data, it can make explicit use of the functions for Windows code pages."

There are a few ways to fix the problem:

1) Ignore it. Sorry, Bruce.

2) Specify that MMDB_open takes a narrow, UTF-8 encoded file path on Windows and update the libmaxminddb and mmdbresolve code accordingly. This would match the behavior of other cross-platform libraries such as GLib and is the solution I'd personally recommend.

3) Specify that MMDB_open takes a wide, UTF-16LE encoded file path on Windows and update the libmaxminddb and mmdbresolve code accordingly.

I'd be glad to help implement 2).

items.title: 1.3.2 tarball contains build-time residue
items.body: t/.deps are files created at compile-time iff certain libtool options are enabled, and contain data highly specific to the local build machine. Therefore, they should not be included in a source release. I'm not sure if there is a 'make distclean' or similar target that has a bug, or some manual intervention was not documented or performed correctly, but libmaxminddb-1.3.2.tar.gz has t/.deps/*.Po that point to linux headers in /usr/include, which is definitely not correct for my darwin (OS X) machine.

items.title: thread safety bug/restrictions?
items.body:
I use libmaxminddb in a highly threaded environment inside my rsyslog project. We have seen segfaults in code regions that use libmaxminddb. Using valgrind's helgrind thread debugger we found at least one data race where libmaxminddb accesses memory that had been passed back to a caller. The caller used the returned data. This use and one of the next calls lead to the race. Details are in our bug tracker (everything in front of the mentioned comment is probably not of interest, it's a very long issue):
https://github.com/rsyslog/rsyslog/issues/1885#issuecomment-344882616

I have researched the libmaxmindb is said to be thread-safe. My question now: is there a data race bug in libmaxminddb or do I do something that is not legally permitted when using the lib. Or more precisely: is it OK to hold on to data returned from libmaxminddb calls when doing the next one or do I need to copy it to a separate buffer?

items.title: Do fewer allocations when constructing data entry list
items.body: Right now, this library is very inefficient in its allocations. It allocates a new `MMDB_entry_data_list_s` separately for each piece of data returned. For a typical GeoIP2 City lookup, this is often between 100-150 allocations for these list entries alone. I made a quick hack where I swapped out the current individual allocations of list entries with one large allocation at the start of the lookup and I saw an 80% improvement in performance.

items.title: mmdblookup usability
items.body:
I've got several small issues with the `mmdblookup` command-line utility.

First of all, its output format is type-annotated pseudo-JSON, which on one hand is too verbose to display in a console (for manual use), and on the other cannot be parsed with existing tools. Ideally, I'd like it to be *actual* parseable JSON, with an option to display something human-readable, like:

```
IP address         : 108.168.255.243
Continent          : North America [NA]
Registered country : United States [US]
Country            : United States [US]
State              : Texas [TX]
City               : Dallas (75270)
Coordinates        : 96.8°W 32.8°N
Time zone          : America/Chicago

IP address         : 2607:f0d0:3:8::4
Continent          : North America [NA]
Registered country : United States [US]
Country            : United States [US]
Coordinates        : 97.8°W 37.8°N
```

The utility also follows the Simon Says school of command-line parsing: it requires me each time to type both `--ip` and `--file` options. I'd much rather simply type `mmdblookup 108.168.255.243`; the program should take any 'unprefixed' command-line arguments as IP addresses, and by default use a database from a well-known location in the file system (somewhere in `/var/lib`). Even better, DNS resolution could be implemented in the utility, so that you could simply run `mmdblookup maxmind.com` without invoking a separate program to resolve the hostname.

Lastly, error messages from the utility contain gratuitous whitespace. The utility also spews the entirety of the built-in help text when it doesn't like the used command-line syntax; I think a 'Run "mmdblookup --help" for usage' message would suffice here. It's what most other command-line programs do.

I can work around all of these deficiencies by wrapping `mmdblookup` in a shell script, but... well, why should I have to?

items.title: C++ "const" warning
items.body:
The following error is emitted when part of a C++ project using a member data handle to MMDB_s in a const method.

```
maxmind/maxminddb.h:195:33: note: initializing argument 1 of ‘MMDB_lookup_result_s MMDB_lookup_string(MMDB_s*, const 
   char*, int*, int*)’
     extern MMDB_lookup_result_s MMDB_lookup_string(MMDB_s *const mmdb,
```

The workaround in C++ is to use `const_cast`, but those should only be used if the source can't be updated.  Please add appropriate const tagging if a C++ compiler is detected.

items.title: include "error"
items.body:
Currently, maxminddb.h includes the config like this:

`#include <maxminddb_config.h>
`
this should be done like this:
`#include "maxminddb_config.h"
`
so it is relative to the location of maxminddb.h (i.e. the same directory.  The current implementation assumes the headers are installed in the include path, which is not always the case.

items.title: Documentation Example error
items.body:
several errors in here: http://maxmind.github.io/libmaxminddb/ 

```
    MMDB_lookup_result_s result =
        MMDB_lookup_string(mmdb, ipstr, &gai_error, &mmdb_error);
```

should take in the ADDRESS of the mmdb:

```
    MMDB_lookup_result_s result =
        MMDB_lookup_string(&mmdb, ipstr, &gai_error, &mmdb_error);
```

items.title: Packaging warning - unused shared library
items.body:
Hi, I saw that there was no AUR package for this lib for Arch Linux, so decided to create it myself. In a nutshell, Arch has a packaging system in place that make it easy to install custom-compiled packages with the package manager.

Packaging it up went allright, but when I checked the package with namcap (a tool to diagnose potential issues), I get a warning about unused shared library:

```
➜  libmaxminddb  namcap libmaxminddb-1.2.0-1-x86_64.pkg.tar.xz
libmaxminddb W: File (.BUILDINFO) exists in a non-standard directory.
libmaxminddb W: Unused shared library '/usr/lib/libm.so.6' by file ('usr/lib/libmaxminddb.so.0.0.7')
```

For packaging, nothing more happened than running the typical `make`, `make install`, as documented in the README. For full reference, the PKGBUILD:

```
# Maintainer: Sergei Maertens <info@regex-it.nl>
pkgname=libmaxminddb
pkgver=1.2.0
pkgrel=1
epoch=
pkgdesc="C library for the MaxMind DB file format http://maxmind.github.io/libmaxminddb/"
arch=('i686' 'x86_64')
```

As part of the installation process, `ldconfig` has run as well.

When googling for similar warnings, most hits say to inquire at upstream, so that's what I'm doing. Should I be worried, or can this be ignored?

items.title: Please provide a way for users to mmap databases with different mmap options or madvise settings
items.body:
The `mmap`ping done by this library is currently very opaque to the user. It's not easily possible to give the kernel any hints about memory management using the various `mmap` flags or `madvise` on the `mmap`ed region.

Exposing options to do so might allow users to tune the libraries behaviour for their use case.

items.title: includedir not respected for maxminddb_config.h
items.body:
In Debian, for co-installation purposes across multiple architectures (a feature called "multi-arch"), it is required that the packages ship identical contents for identical filenames across different architectures.

Since `maxminddb_config.h` varies by architecture (MMDB_UINT128_IS_BYTE_ARRAY is set to 1 on e.g. i386 but 0 on e.g. amd64, assuming recent toolchain), the only way to do this is to ship header files to /usr/include/<architecture triplet/ which is supported by the Debian toolchain as an include path.

I attempted to do so by passing `--includedir` to `configure`, but this resulted into this:

```
-rw-r--r-- root/root      7069 2015-07-19 02:31 ./usr/include/x86_64-linux-gnu/maxminddb.h
-rw-r--r-- root/root      6429 2015-07-19 02:31 ./usr/include/x86_64-linux-gnu/maxminddb-compat-util.h
-rw-r--r-- root/root       507 2015-07-19 02:31 ./usr/include/maxminddb_config.h
```

My autoconf foo isn't great, but the above diff seems to fix this:

``` diff
--- a/Makefile.am
+++ b/Makefile.am
@@ -1,7 +1,7 @@

 include_HEADERS = include/maxminddb.h src/maxminddb-compat-util.h

-include_execdir = $(exec_prefix)/include
+include_execdir = $(includedir)

 nodist_include_exec_HEADERS = include/maxminddb_config.h

```

items.title: Homebrew package not installing as universal
items.body:
This is the other end of the problem listed in https://github.com/maxmind/MaxMind-DB-Reader-python/issues/2.

On Yosemite, Homebrew appears to install a 64 bit only version of libmaxminddb. This then will cause the Python extension to fail compile. The workaround is to force a universal install of libmaxminddb through brew (brew install --universal libmaxminddb), but since this is not the default many people won't do this. The bottle is not generated with --universal either.

libmaxminddb should probably always build as universal on OS X to avoid these compatibility issues.

items.title: Slight rework of the VS12 project
items.body:
I reworked the VS12 project to minimize maintenance required by moving most settings to property pages and also to address the issue when x64 build wiped out some intermediate files for Win32 builds. This is the patch I created by merging your changes with mine (as of today). You may want to revisit your new test projects to avoid same problems. 

You can reproduce the problem by rebuilding a Debug Win32 configuration and follow up with a Debug x64 rebuild and you will see that a bunch of files disappeared from Debug. I didn't notice this problem initially because I'm in the process of converting my own project to x64 and I wasn't building x64 targets at the time.

If you want to the the same with your projects, the basic logic here is to keep the main property page file (similar to `libmaxminddb.props`) as Debug|Win32 and override these properties for Release and x64 builds in, such as in `libmaxminddb-x64.props` and `libmaxminddb-release.props`. You will need to create three more property files for the new test projects and share them across all projects in a similar way. This will allow you to change the configuration in just one place. 

Here's the patch. The test projects didn't build for m, so I'm assuming it's work in progress and didn't change anything in them. Let me know if you need any help with those. 

```
From f2f0a093ec5efa584c6e437c68a3a1379f2702d1 Mon Sep 17 00:00:00 2001
From: Stone Steps <support@stonesteps.ca>
Date: Sun, 14 Dec 2014 13:25:10 -0500
Subject: [PATCH] Added x64 and Release VS12 property pages

---
 projects/VS12/README                       | 52 ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
 projects/VS12/libmaxminddb-release.props   | 32 ++++++++++++++++++
 projects/VS12/libmaxminddb-x64.props       | 14 ++++++++
 projects/VS12/libmaxminddb.props           | 15 +++++++--
 projects/VS12/libmaxminddb.vcxproj         | 20 ++++--------
 projects/VS12/libmaxminddb.vcxproj.filters |  3 ++
 6 files changed, 120 insertions(+), 16 deletions(-)
 create mode 100644 projects/VS12/README
 create mode 100644 projects/VS12/libmaxminddb-release.props
 create mode 100644 projects/VS12/libmaxminddb-x64.props

diff --git a/projects/VS12/README b/projects/VS12/README
new file mode 100644
index 0000000..8be5879
--- /dev/null
+++ b/projects/VS12/README
@@ -0,0 +1,52 @@
+Project Notes
+
+DO NOT modify project settings for each configuration and/or platform
+on a per-project basis. Use property sheets to set shared configuration
+properties. The rule of thumb - if you set same value for the same 
+property in more than one configuration or platform, you did it wrong.
+
+libmaxminddb.props
+
+This is the base property sheet for libMaxMindDB project. It contains 
+settings that are shared between all configurations, such as compiler
+warning level, not using link-time code generation, etc.
+
+In order to minimize the number of property sheet files, this propery
+sheet also contains settings for Win32 and Debug configurations, which 
+are overridden by the x64 and Release property sheets described below.
+
+libmaxminddb-release.props
+
+This property sheet contains all Release settings and is shared between
+Win32 and x64 release builds. It must be located higher than the base
+property sheet in the property Manager window for each configuration
+where it's used (i.e. Release|Win32 and Release|x64).
+
+libmaxminddb-x64.props
+
+This property sheet contains all x64 settings and is shared between all 
+Debug and Release x64 configurations. It must be located higher than the 
+base property sheet in the property Manager window for each configuration
+where it's used (i.e. Debug|x64 and Release|x64).
+
+Adding More Projects
+
+If you want to add more projects into this solution, follow the same logic
+and create their own property sheets. Do not use libmaxminddb property 
+sheets in those projects because it will interfere with their intermediate 
+directories. Instead, copy and rename libmaxminddb property sheets as a
+starting point.
+
+DO NOT add libmaxminddb.lib to the Additional Dependencies box of command
+line tools or any other libraries you built, for that matter. This box is
+only for standard Windows libraries. Instead, add libmaxminddb as a reference
+to all command line tool projects. Do the same for any other library projects
+you added to this solutionn. 
+
+For external 3rd-party .lib files, create a solution folder called Libraries 
+and add Debug, Debug64, Release, Release64 subfolders, then drag and drop all 
+versinos of .lib to their respective folders and use Exclude From Build in 
+each library file's property to assign them to the proper build confguration.
+Unused libraries will be shown with a traffic stop sign in each configuration. 
+If you have a lot of projects, it might be easier to do this by editing .vcxproj 
+and .vcxproj.filters in a text editor.
```

items.title: The last argument in CreateFileMappingA is the name of the mapping object, not the file name
items.body:
This call will fail because the last argument is supposed to be the name of the mapping object in case if you want to share it between multiple processes, not the name of the file you are mapping, and in this case it should be `NULL` because you don't need to name it.

```
HANDLE mmh = CreateFileMappingA(fd, NULL, PAGE_READONLY, 0, size, filename);
```

There's a couple of other issues, such as `ssize_t` and `restricted` are not defined in VS2013, so they need to be `#ifdef`'ed. 

You can see the complete VS2013 patch, including the project files here:

https://stonestepswebalizer.codeplex.com/SourceControl/latest#patches/maxminddb/vs12-project.patch

items.title: Linking libmaxminddb on Solaris needs "-lsocket"
items.body:
Symbols getaddrinfo(), freeaddrinfo() and gai_strerror() must be linked with "-lsocket" on Solaris:

Excerpt from man page:

Sockets Library Functions                    getaddrinfo(3SOCKET)

NAME
     getaddrinfo,  getnameinfo,  freeaddrinfo,   gai_strerror   -
     translate between node name and address

SYNOPSIS
     cc [ flag... ] file ... -lsocket  -lnsl  [ library ... ]
     #include <sys/socket.h>
     #include <netdb.h>

...

Error during "make":

Undefined                       first referenced
 symbol                             in file
__xnet_getaddrinfo                  ../src/.libs/libmaxminddb.so
freeaddrinfo                        ../src/.libs/libmaxminddb.so
gai_strerror                        mmdblookup.o
ld: fatal: Symbol referencing errors. No output written to .libs/mmdblookup

Possible solution: add "-lsocket" to libmaxminddb_la_LIBADD in src/Makefile on Solaris. As far as I can see, "-lnsl" is not strictly needed. libsocket itself has libnsl as a dependency.

Using
      AC_SEARCH_LIBS(getaddrinfo, socket)
in configure.ac would add -lsocket to LIBS like you already do for -lm testing "fabs". Note that then all shared objects, the libmaxminddb and the mmdblookup binary would be linked against the socket lib. That doesn't break mmdblookup, it's just unneeded there. But since you do currently not care about linking everything against libm, you might not care about linking anything against libsocket either.
